title: 9 Successful PR Campaign Examples, According to the Data
description: From Barbie-themed ketchup to exploding owl butts, these campaign examples prove that PR can drive real, measurable results.
content: Louise Linehan Louise is a Content Marketer at Ahrefs. Over the past ten years, she has held senior content positions at SaaS brands: Pi Datametrics, BuzzSumo, and Cision. By day, she writes about content and SEO; by night, you'll find her playing football or screaming down the mic at karaoke. In this post, youâ€™ll see the data behind nine successful PR campaigns, and hopefully get some inspiration for your next press idea.Contents9 popular PR campaign examplesThis list is a real mixed bag of PR examples â€“ from newsjacking, to content repurposing, exclusive research, and kooky brand stunts â€“ but one thing they all have in common is measurable success.In each section, Iâ€™ll do a post-mortem of campaign performance, share some analysis tactics, and round-off with a couple of quick tips.Sound good? Letâ€™s jump in.1. Heinz + Mattel â€œBarbiecueâ€ PR campaignCampaign ğŸ…ğŸ‘±ğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸ğŸ€Heinz BarbiecueBrand(s) ğŸ·ï¸Heinz + MattelLinks earned ğŸ”—62Campaign type ğŸ“°Newjacking/brand collab/product releaseGlobal search volume ğŸ”600 for â€œbarbie ketchupâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ200% for â€œbarbie ketchupâ€Back in August 2023, when Barbiecore was all the rage, Heinz teased a mockup of two Barbie themed sauces: Kenchup and Barbiecue sauce.Eight months later, for Barbieâ€™s 65th anniversary in April 2024, Heinz and Mattel dropped the official Barbiecue special edition sauce.Heinz first conceived of the PR stunt to build intrigue around the product months before it hit the shelves, then used public response as a litmus test for its success.According to their submission in the Shorty Awards, they carefully coordinated their initial â€œteaserâ€ drop to coincide with an uptick in audience discussions, following the filmâ€™s release.To date, the Barbiecue PR campaign has earned Heinz 118 relevant mentions in top-tier media outlets like Bloomberg, Yahoo, CBS News, and The Standard, according to Content Explorer.With zero dollars in paid promotion, it also generated 38 million organic social impressions and doubled average engagement rates.Quick learningsHijack trending cultural â€œmomentsâ€Time your PR campaign launch with peak online conversationUse teaser PR to gauge consumer demand and fuel future R&D decisions 2. Lush Saltburn bath bombCampaign ğŸ›€SaltbombBrand ğŸ·ï¸LushLinks earned ğŸ”—142Campaign type ğŸ“°Newjacking/product releaseGlobal search volume ğŸ”1.3K for â€œlush saltburn bath bombâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ37K% for â€œlush saltburn bath bombâ€This is another great PR example of a brand capitalizing on a film, and waiting for post-event discussion to pick up before newsjacking.Following a veerryy controversial bath scene in the film Saltburn, UK cosmetics retailer, Lush, jumped on the opportunity to insert their brand into a cultural moment.In February 2024, three months after the filmâ€™s release, they released the â€œSaltbombâ€, a special edition, Saltburn-themed bath bomb.Parodying some of the filmâ€™s most risquÃ© moments, Lush didnâ€™t hold back with their product marketing.And we loved it.The campaign led to 135 links, many coming from high DR (Domain Rating) publications, driving real, tangible organic traffic â€“ including Global News, New York Times, Pop Sugar, and BBC.Press coverage actually went above and beyond this, because Lushâ€™s products are part of a few publisher affiliate programs â€“ but affiliate links are a little trickier to track.Hereâ€™s an example of what I mean.The site Allure wrote up a feature piece on the Lush bath bomb, but their affiliate link navigates to a third-party platform before redirecting to Lushâ€™s product page.For that reason, the link doesnâ€™t show up in Ahrefsâ€™ Backlinks Report.Instead, I found it by monitoring campaign-specific keywords in Content Explorer.Beyond press and affiliate publicity, the Lush PR campaign was a winner on social media.The photography and product descriptions made it perfect for meme-ification, which added thousands of views and impressions.It also won big in search, with global keyword volume reaching 1.3Kâ€¦And the product landing page earned up to 800 monthly organic visits in its first month.Traffic has remained steady since, averaging between 500 - 600 monthly visits, despite the product having been archived â€“ pretty good going for a bit of trendjacking.Quick learningsScout for affiliate links â€“ you wonâ€™t always know when a publisher plans to use an affiliate link, so searching for mentions of campaign keywords can help you find any affiliate coverage that has flown under the radar.Think about how your brand and its tangential topics can tie into cultural moments. 3. Pinterestâ€™s â€œEclectic Grandpaâ€ trendCampaign ğŸ‘´ğŸ»Eclectic GrandpaBrand ğŸ·ï¸PinterestLinks earned ğŸ”—98Campaign type ğŸ“‘ReportGlobal search volume ğŸ”4.8K for â€œeclectic grandpaâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ215K% for â€œeclectic grandpaâ€Every year, Pinterest taps into their internal platform search data to post their trend forecasts in what is known as â€œPinterest Predictsâ€.Posting on Pinterest For Business (the companyâ€™s commercial arm), they categorize related high-growth searches, and assign them novel trend names like â€œEclectic grandpaâ€, â€œBow stackingâ€ or â€œCafe coreâ€.I took a look at the Site Structure report, and found that Pinterestâ€™s most linked trend was in fact the â€œEclectic Grandpaâ€ which â€“ in Pinterestâ€™s words â€“ is all about: â€œEmbracing â€˜grandpa coreâ€™ and bringing eccentric and expressive elements for the ages to wardrobes. Think retro streetwear, chic cardigans and customised clothing. Because the coastal grandma aesthetic is so last year.â€The Pinterest Team, Pinterest PredictsTo date, the trend has earned citations from 98 separate domains.A look at the Backlinks report revealed coverage from Vogue, Elle, Who What Wear, New York Post, and Business Insider.And it didnâ€™t end there. The â€œEclectic Grandpaâ€ gets about a bit, cropping up 340 times in the articles I discovered via Content Explorer.A considerable number of those DR 50+ mentions (150, to be precise) went unlinked based on Ahrefsâ€™ Unlinked Mentions filter/export â€“ links which could still be claimed by the Pinterest team.Given the far reaching coverage, searches for â€œEclectic Grandpaâ€ keywords have shot up in the last year, growing to 4.8K global search volume (GSV). By creating link magnet content, Pinterest has managed to drum up huge publicity â€“ whether they pitched for it or not â€“ making it a great example of a successful PR campaign.Quick learningsMine company data to publish new, unseen trends and insights.Come up with a unique name for self-discovered trends and/or theories so itâ€™s easier to monitor uptake and keep track of press coverage.Track mentions â€“ not just links â€“ and claim any unlinked mentions to enhance SEO and brand authority.4. Zillowâ€™s rate locked homeownersCampaign ğŸ”’ğŸ¡Rate-locked homeownersBrand ğŸ·ï¸ZillowLinks earned ğŸ”—235Campaign type ğŸ—³ï¸SurveyReal estate marketplace, Zillow, surveyed 1,815 homeowners and found that those with lower mortgage rates are twice as likely to stay put vs selling their home.By creating firsthand research tackling an issue close to their audienceâ€™s heart, Zillow earned 235 backlinks from the likes of Bloomberg, Yahoo, FoxBusiness, and Money.com.Sites referenced the survey for multiple reasons; not just quoting one stat, but a whole variety, as evidenced in the anchor text of their backlinks.Quick learningsConduct your own surveys, asking questions which address a key problem in your industry, then quantitatively analyze the responses.Tease out multiple hard hitting stats to drive more coverage and link variety.5. LinkedInâ€™s future of workCampaign ğŸ”®ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»Future of WorkBrand ğŸ·ï¸LinkedInLinks earned ğŸ”—383Campaign type ğŸ“‘ReportGlobal search volume ğŸ”300 for â€œLinkedIn reportâ€LinkedIn tends to keep their data under lock and key, but in their Future of Work report they released proprietary insights on the growth of AI conversations on the platform, plus the impact of AI on careers.A great example of exclusive PR, LinkedInâ€™s report made a splash, landing 383 links in Forbes, Microsoft, Harvard Business Review, and CNET.Quick learningsThink about what unseen or underground data you can harvest to generate exclusive research for your next PR campaign.If you have internal data, analyze patterns and trends to carve out a totally unique angle..Tip Look at your internal site search data in GA4 (thanks to Mark Williams-Cook and Julius Fedorovicius for the tip!) or any other firsthand information at your disposal, to mine insights. If you canâ€™t make use of primary data, tap into third-party sources. PR expert, Matt Seabridge, routinely shares some great data sources and PR campaign examples via his newsletter The Digital PR Observer â€“ I really recommend subscribing. 6. WalletHubâ€™s most & least educated citiesCampaign ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ“ğŸ™ï¸Most & Least Educated Cities in AmericaBrand ğŸ·ï¸WalletHubLinks earned ğŸ”—604Campaign type ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»Interactive StudyPersonal finance company, WalletHub, compared the 150 largest metropolitan statistical areas, or MSAs, across 11 key metrics.Combining primary data with third-party sources like the U.S. Census Bureau, GreatSchools.org, and Yelp, WalletHub created an interactive study ranking the most and least educated cities in America.This is an example of a PR campaign that doubles as great content marketing.It snagged 604 unique backlinks from heavy hitters like Wikipedia, Forbes, Business Insider, Bloomberg, and Yahoo â€“ as well as tons of state publications.Location based PR campaigns are an especially powerful form of PR, since they have both local and national appeal.Hereâ€™s Tom Chivers, PR Expert and Founder of Sabot, explaining why localization really works for public relations campaigns â€“ with a great additional point made by Co-Founder of Journo Finder, Veronica Fletcher.Quick learningsUse superlatives in headlines (e.g. â€œMostâ€, â€œLeastâ€, â€œBestâ€).Embrace ranking formats â€“ comparisons make readers want to click to see how they size up.Slice and dice your data by location to get your campaign syndicated in both national and local publications.7. Krispy Kreme â€œGo USAâ€ and â€œPassport to Parisâ€ Olympic doughnutsCampaign ğŸ©â€œGo USAâ€ and â€œPassport to Parisâ€ doughnutsBrand(s) ğŸ·ï¸Krispy KremeLinks earned ğŸ”—95Campaign type ğŸ“°Newjacking/brand collab/product releaseGlobal search volume ğŸ”45K for â€œOlympics Krispy Kreme Doughnutsâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ4.4M% for â€œOlympics Krispy Kreme Doughnutsâ€Krispy Kreme rode the wave of Olympic interest this year by developing two special edition doughnuts: â€œGo USAâ€ and â€œPassport to Parisâ€.As weâ€™ve seen already, popular PR campaigns donâ€™t always neatly track back to the sources youâ€™d expect them to.Krispy Kreme earned only 11 links to their USA doughnut press release, and 20 to their Paris doughnut launch announcement. Not exactly groundbreaking.But when you filter for mentions of campaign keywords (e.g. â€œGo USAâ€ and â€œParisâ€) at the domain-level, you find a whole lot more coverage; 95 links, to be precise, from major publications like Yahoo, USA Today, People, and the Food Network.The special edition doughnuts also drive a cool 45K monthly searches, according to the Matching Terms report in Keywords Explorer.Quick learningsCapitalize on high demand around recurring events.For campaigns that canâ€™t be neatly tracked (e.g. no specific landing page, or product page) pay closer attention to homepage or domain-level links through clever filtering.8. McDonaldâ€™s + Crocs collaborationCampaign ğŸŸğŸ‘McDonaldâ€™s + Crocs CollaborationBrand(s) ğŸ·ï¸Crocs + McDonaldâ€™sLinks earned ğŸ”—516Campaign type ğŸ“°Brand collab/product releaseGlobal search volume ğŸ”18K for â€œmcdonalds crocsâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ838% for â€œmcdonalds crocsâ€This next PR example is a campaign of multiple parts. It began with a pair of McDonaldâ€™s themed Crocs, and has extended to a full blown footwear collectionâ€¦And a novelty product: McDonaldâ€™s happy meal mini-crocs keyring.The coordinated PR campaign has generated huge awareness for both brands, but tracking all the fragmented assets is no mean feat.To get a better idea of overall brand awareness, I opted instead to search for co-citations at the domain level.Searching in the Backlinks report, I applied filters for each brand name in the otherâ€™s backlink profile.McDonaldâ€™s earned 260 links for â€œCrocsâ€ related content, but Crocs was the real winner, landing 416 links for â€œMcDonaldâ€™sâ€ related press from media goliaths like Business Insider, Fast Company, and Entrepreneur.From studying the campaignâ€™s individual assets, I noticed something interesting: social posts have the ability to attract links.Take for instance, this UGC post by Instagram food account, Snackolater. It landed 24 backlinks after sharing news of the happy meal mini-croc launch.It had never occurred to me to track social media posts for links, but you can never tell how a journalist is going to reference your campaign, so itâ€™s worthwhile setting up a backlink alert for all your assets just in case!The growth of brand searches is a real testament to the success of a PR campaign, and this collaboration definitely delivers on that front.Audiences are searching for relevant McDonaldâ€™s + Croc based keywords a total of 37K times a month on average, based on data in Keywords Explorer.Quick learningsSometimes, the â€œsideâ€ brand in a collaboration can snag more links. Keep that in mind for your next PR partnership.With two brands there are double the assets to track, including product pages, press releases, landing pages, and various social posts â€“ make sure you have purview over the performance of all moving parts to track public relations campaigns holistically.Donâ€™t forget to report on social posts, not just for impressions/engagement but for links.9. Duolingo â€œNo butsâ€ Super Bowl commercialCampaign âğŸ‘Do your lesson, no butsBrand(s) ğŸ·ï¸Duo LingoLinks earned ğŸ”—130Campaign type ğŸ“½ï¸AdvertGlobal search volume ğŸ”250 for â€œDuolingo commercialâ€Search growth (YoY) ğŸ“ˆ376% for â€œDuolingo commercialâ€Duolingo leaned into their weird yet wonderful brand of marketing with a hilarious superbowl ad featuring Duo, the brandâ€™s menacing owl character.In 5 (wild) seconds, we witness the explosion of Duoâ€™s butt, and the growth of a mini Duo in its place, accompanied by a reminder to do our Duo Lingo lesson.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QPjgXWm7F6cThe ad creative was repurposed from a widget design that went semi-viral â€“ Duo Lingo knew it worked, so they built on it.And in a stroke of coordinated PR genius, they simultaneously sent out a push-notification to app users as soon as the ad went live. â€œWe decided to pair the ad with a coordinated push notification, which would hit learnersâ€™ phones right after the commercial aired, reinforcing the idea that Duo is always watching .â€The Duo Lingo Team, Duo Lingo BlogThe YouTube commercial has earned 5M views and 130 links from Gizmodo, Lifehacker, and Indy100.Plus 24M plays on TikTok.The Duolingo team have written up a seriously funny play-by-play of the PR campaign here â€“ they talk about everything from the lengths they went to to get the right â€œshineâ€ on Duoâ€™s buttocks, to carefully selecting the perfect fart sound effect. I recommend reading it, for a giggle if nothing else.Quick learningsUpcycle owned content that has worked well in the past for your next PR campaign.Try a mixed-message approach to really drive the point of your campaign home.How I found these PR campaign examples (and you can too)I spent a lot of time:In Ahrefs Content Explorer searching for examples of typical PR campaign headlinesFlicking through the back catalog of Campaign Inspiration, PR Week Campaigns, The Grapevine, and The PR Insider (p.s. Iâ€™ve since come across two more databases full of hundreds more ace PR campaigns â€“ theyâ€™re definitely worth a bookmark: Digital PR Tips from Matt Seabridge and The PRchive from digitaloft)Snooping on the Top Pages of brand websites to spot press/link magnetsThere were so many awesome examples of PR, but I narrowed it down to the ones that drove either press mentions, links, search volume, traffic, or all of the above.Final thoughtsThe best PR campaigns arenâ€™t just about links. Theyâ€™re about creating conversations, driving awareness, and making a lasting impact on your audience.Hereâ€™s a quick recap of some of the top takeaways:Time it right: Launch your campaigns when conversations peakTap into unique data: Use exclusive insights to stand outTrack holistically: Monitor links, mentions, searches, and socialRank and compare: Engage multiple audience â€œtribesâ€ through rankingsTake a local angle: Analyze multiple locations to win more pressCollaborate creatively: Brand partnerships can amplify your reachRepurpose winners: Turn successful content into new campaignsSuccess is predicated on a campaign meeting its goal(s), and while we donâ€™t know exactly what these brands set out to achieve, their campaigns have enjoyed results that most of us would be pretty happy with.Hopefully theyâ€™ve given you some inspiration for your next project.
